data.stimulus:
1.1. Resource 1

Kilroy, P. (1971) ‘Relationship between ethics and equal opportunities in the workplace’ Journal of International Business, 18(5), 21-38.

response.value: Because the year is 1971 which is before 2000/ not recent, and it is about business and not mentions education/ not relevant.

data.stimulus:
1.2. Resource 2

Wilson, S. (2017) ‘Implementing ethical guidelines in the 21st century’ International Journal of Veterinarians, 41(2), 671-677.

response.value: Because it is not mentions leadership and it is not for education/ not relevant.

metadata.sample_answer: it’s for veterinarians and therefore not related to education (it’s not relevant).

data.stimulus:
1.3. Resource 3

Robson, R. (2015) Handbook of the Ethical Manager. Cambridge University Press

response.value: It is relevant, recent and reliable.

metadata.sample_answer: the topic is related to ethical leadership (it’s relevant), it’s reliable and it’s recent.

data.stimulus:
1.4. Resource 4

Leading Tips (2019) How to Be an Ethical Leader. www.youtube.com/watch=Fiso45ktsg2yw

response.value: Because it is a tips in youtube which is not about academic, expert and authority/ not reliable.

metadata.sample_answer: it’s a youtube video and therefore it’s not reliable.

data.stimulus:
1.5. Resource 5

Ericksen, M. (2017) ‘Ethics in academia: challenges managing modern educational systems’ International Journal of Management, 46(7), 67-75.

response.value: Because it is relevant, recent and reliable.

metadata.sample_answer: the topic is related to education and the ethical leadership (it’s relevant), it’s reliable and it’s recent.

options.label: Consumers worldwide vary tremendously in age, education income, education level and tastes.
Consumers buy a wide variety of goods throughout their lives.
Social factors such as groups, word-of-mouth, opinion leaders and social networks affect people’s choices of products, services and companies.
Two types of groups influence consumer behaviour: membership groups and reference groups.
Identifying the target market’s reference groups helps marketers influence consumer behaviour.
Strong brands have more control over reference groups and can pressure consumers to choose their products.
Consumers trust their friends and family more than commercial sources (e.g., advertisements or salespeople).
It’s impossible for marketers to control word-of-mouth because most of its influence happens naturally.
Consumers have mostly positive conversations about the brands they feel strongly about.
Opinion leaders are experts who can influence consumer behaviour.
Opinion leaders can help a brand become popular with target consumers.
Opinion leaders help marketers identify products which are suitable for their target consumers.
There are several types of social networking communities (e.g., blogs, message boards, social media sites and communal shopping sites).
Social networking communities enable consumers to create closer connections with the brands they buy.
Social networking communities enable brands to send more one-way commercial messages to consumers.
A university student buying a new laptop.
A fashion company buying fur to make expensive coats
A family buying plane tickets to go on their summer holiday.
A person buying office furniture (e.g. desk and chair) to work from home .

data.stimulus:
Task 2 – Main ideas and Supporting Points

Based on the information from text A, choose the correct answer: a, b, c or d.

options.label: Consumer behaviour is directly influenced by reference groups.
Reference groups serve as a starting point in a person's attitudes or behaviour.
Consumers pick up new behaviours and lifestyles from reference groups.
Reference groups make products visible to others whom the buyer respects.
The vast majority of consumers don’t believe any form of advertising.
The vast majority of consumers don’t believe the personal words and recommendations of their friends and family.
Only a small number of consumers believe the personal words and recommendations of trusted friends and family.
Only a small number of consumers consider advertising more credible than recommendations from friends and family.
They do not use social networks to promote their products and brands effectively.
They are focusing on the implications of business-to-consumer dialogue.
They use social networks to talk to consumers and get involved in their conversations and lives.
They are helping brands share their passions and experiences with consumers in both real and digital worlds.

data.stimulus:
Task 1 – Identifying author’s viewpoint.

Use the information in text B to decide if the sentences are TRUE or FALSE. 

Justify your answer with a sentence from text B.

response.value: More than ever before. it' s crucial for business to go beyond the digital space to build meaningful relationships.

data.stimulus: 1.1.1. Justify your answer with a sentence from text B.

metadata.sample_answer: More than ever before, it’s crucial for businesses to go beyond the digital space to build meaningful relationships.

response.value: Marketers didn't have the appropriate tools to track their event programs from end to end.

data.stimulus: 1.2.1. Justify your answer with a sentence from text B.

metadata.sample_answer: it’s no longer acceptable for event marketers to report on informal results.

response.value: Whose event schedule never seems to slow down and can often include multiple events in different parts of the world.

data.stimulus: 1.3.1. Justify your answer with a sentence from text B.

metadata.sample_answer: Early event management software programs were helpful in planning and managing events, but lacked the tools needed to track what those events were delivering for the companies.

response.value: Not only better to calculate a return on their investment events, but are also more confidently expanding their event budgets for event marketing.

it seems inevitable that more organizations will join them.
